projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A MOST STRANGE AND VVONDERFVLL PROPHESIE VPON THIS TROVBLESOME world. Calculated by the famous Doctor in A≈øtrologie, Mai≈øter Iohn Cypriano, conferred with the iudgements of Iames Marchecel≈øus and Sinnior Guiuardo, three excellent A≈øtronomers vnder the Emperour of Chri≈øtendom: ≈øent out of Germany into Italy, to the Vniuer≈øitie of Padua, to the rare≈øt Nigromancer in the world.
Wherevnto is annexed Tarquatus Vandermers ≈øeauen yeres ≈øtudy in the Arte of Magick, vpon the twelue moneths of the yeare, where many ≈øecrets are reuealed vnto the vvorld.
Tran≈ølated out of Italian by Anth. Hollaway Gent.

figure.figDesc: a man with an astrolabe quadrant views the moon and stars while two others talk over a book. A horned devil is central to their conversation.

div.p:
Imprinted at London
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ

div.head: A MOST STRANGE AND VVONDERFVLL PROPHESIE VPON THIS TROVBLESOME WORLD.
div.p:
OXford and Cambridge, VVittenberge and Padua, you glorious Vniuer≈øities of Chri≈øtendome, take truce for a ≈øea≈øon vvith your deepe in≈øpiring ≈øciences, and vouch≈øafe to fixe your inienious iudgements vppon this rare and vvonderfull Prophe≈øie, calculated by the famous and excellent Doctor in A≈øtrologie, Ma≈øter Iohn Cypriano A≈øtronomer vnder the Emperour of Chri≈øtendome, agreeable to the iudgments of Iames Marche≈øel≈øus, and Sinnior Guiuardo, tvvo learned Clarkes in Germany, the like vvas neuer published in anie age, for the angry heauens by fearefull vi≈øions, foredooming Commets, and ≈øtrange coniunction of Planets dooth progno≈øticate to this ≈øynfull vvorld, the alteration of kingdomes, fall of Princes, ouerthrovv of comman vvealths, de≈øolation of countries, the ruine of Citties, Tovvnes, and Villages, earthquakes, flouds, and mighty tempe≈øts, vvherby the vvhole vvorld vvil be greatly anoyde, al≈øo by the variable cour≈øe of the ellements, all nations vnder the cercute of the ≈øunne, vvil be grieuou≈øly vexed vvith bloudie vvarres famine, death, ≈øcar≈øitie, vvith many other
≈øtrange and fearefull accidents, as vvell in Europe as in Affrica and A≈øia, al vvhich is for our vvickedne≈ø≈øe and ≈øynnes, vvherein the vvhole earth is drovvned as in a gulfe, pa≈øt all recouerie, except the maie≈øty of God be mercifull: to auoide the manifolde mi≈øeries that is likely to fall vpon the face of the earth: and our learned A≈øtrologi≈øions hath published this fearefull and vvonderfull Prophe≈øie to mooue vs to a penitent life, that God may vvithhold his grieuous ≈øcorge from vs My≈øtically ≈øet dovvne, for a Gla≈ø≈øe or example to them that vnder≈øtand and are vvi≈øe to looke into and for a di≈ødaine and reproofe to them that are foolish, as hereafter follovveth.

In the Northen borders of the earth, is ≈øcituated a Forre≈øt trianglevvi≈øe, inuironed vvith a vvall of Bra≈ø≈øe from vvhich forre≈øt shall flie a fortunate foule that shall ≈øvvim euen to the borders of Affrica, and there light vpon a golden Tree, from vvhence shee shall pull three branches of gold, and ≈øo triumphantly returne backe to the Forre≈øt againe: at vvhich there shall an Eagle that builds her ne≈øt vpon a golden ≈øteeple ≈øo much repine, and ≈øend foorth many ≈øecret fiers to burne and vva≈øte the ≈øaid Forre≈øt, but euery one shal be quenched and quite extinguished before the blaze
be kindled. Many Princes of the earth shall ≈øeeke by pollicy to hunt therein, but at the gates thereof shall take a great repul≈øe: ≈øo fortunate and frutefull shall this Forre≈øt be, and ≈øo inuincible her tovvers of bra≈ø≈øe, that all the kingdomes of the earth shall admire her fortitude, and grace her vvith the title of that ble≈ø≈øed Pardice, vvhich God gaue Adam at the vvorlds creation. After this the Sea shall be mightier then the land, for there the corners of the vvorld shall meete and fight a tirrible battell, vvherein a mightie man shall be ouer throvvne.

In the VVea≈øt shall lurke a bloudie Serpent in a Denne, vvhich hath not ≈øeene the light the≈øe many yeares, but yet this bloudie Serpent shall haue many ≈øtings, vvhich shall ≈øtretche into all the corners of Europe, & be annoyance to the vvhole ≈øtate of Chri≈øtendome: Then from the Northe shall corne a Dragon, that shall breake out the Serpents teeth, and pluck foorth his ≈øtings that he shall neither bite nor ≈øting, yet shall the Serpent keepe his Den, and receiue ≈øuccour from the Eagle in the golden ≈øteeple.
In the South shall liue a VVolfe vpon the commons bloud, and quaffe dovvne tovvn ‚Ä¢ into his thir≈øtie throate but in the midde≈øt of this bloudie danquet shall he choake him≈øelfe and die.

Out of the Ea≈øt shall come a di≈ømall blacke Dogge, that like a theefe by night shall enter Germanie in vvhich enterpri≈øe he shall loo≈øe one of his limbes, and ≈øo depart vvith ≈øuch an yeelping ≈øound, at vvhich the limmets of Affrica and A≈øia shall quake. This Dogge shall aftervvard for≈øake his mai≈øter, and choo≈øe him a nevv name, vvhereby the Scriptures shall be fulfilled. This Dog doth ≈øignifie the Turke, vvhich shall for≈øake his Mahomet, and choo≈øe to him the name of Chri≈øtian, vvhich is a ≈øigne the day of doombe is at hand, vvhen all the earth is ≈øubiect to one God.
The Flovver de Luce and France, shall liue long at varience, but at length agree.

The bovvels of Spaine shall be ≈øpilt in ≈øunder, and deuided for vvant of gouernment, euen in tho≈øe dayes vvhen the golden ≈øteeple shal be con≈øumed vvith fire euen that ≈øeauen headed citie, novv more brauer then Ieru≈øalem shall be a place more de≈øolate then Ieru≈øalem. Then shall the cleare vvord ≈øpring foorth and florish through the vvorld, vvhich neuer shall be taken from vs again, after this a milke vvhite Doue shal be lifted vp to honour by tvvo golden Lions, and receaue a crovvne of gould.

But after all the≈øe things shall the end of the vvorld approch, therefore shall there be heauie and pittifull dayes vvith much vvarres and other alterations of the vvorld, all vvhich is likely to en≈øue this yeare follovving.

div.head:
Tarquatus Vandermers, ≈øeauen yeares ≈øtudie in the Arte of Magicke, vpon the tvvelue moneths of the yeare: wherein many ≈øecrets are reueald vnto the world.
a man with an astrolabe quadrant views the moon and stars while two others talk over a book. A horned devil is central to their conversation.
IANVARIE. 1569.
div.p:
In the moneth of Ianuarie, the angrie heauens doe foretell, vpon that land vvhere mo≈øt ≈øin and vvickedne≈ø≈øe
dooth abound, shall raigne a shovver of bloud continuing for the ≈øpace of an houre, vvhich dooth progno≈øticate the de≈øtruction of that vnhappie region.

div.head: FEBRVARIE.
div.p: In February, rumours of vvars shall fill the eares of all nations, euery kingdom vnder the frame of heauen shall mu≈øter vvell approoued ≈øouldiers: traffick by ≈øea shall be denied betvvixt land & land, and euery countrey shall be for≈øt to liue vpon his ovvne.

div.head: MARCHE.
div.p: In Marche, the maine Seas shall bee ≈øo troubled vvith mighty tempe≈øts and vvindes, that they shall ≈øvvell aboue their bankes, and ouerflovve an I≈øland vvhere the double cro≈ø≈øe hath gouernment, onely becau≈øe the ≈øinnes of the Prince is ≈øo hainous before the Maie≈øtie of God.

div.head: APRILL.
div.p:
In Aprill shall happen ≈øuch a terrible battell on the ≈øea, vvhereby the vvater vvill be turned to the couler of bloud, more ≈øanguinlike then is the redde ≈øeas: God
for his mercy turn it to the be≈øt, and defend our innocent and ≈øpotle≈ø≈øe bloud of England.

div.head: MAYE.
div.p: In Maye the earth shall bee ouer burthend vvith bloudie vvarres, and ≈øome nations shall furnish forth ≈øo many ≈øouldiers, vvhereby the land shall be ≈øo de≈øolate of men, that ≈øeauen vvomen shall bee con≈øtrained to follovv one man.

div.head: IVNE.
div.p: In Iune, a prouince in the Ea≈øterne climbes: shall fight in the defence of a vvrongful cau≈øe, at vvhich the Maie≈øtie of God vvill threaten vengeance, and raine dovvne fire from the throne of heauen, and ≈øo burne tho≈øe vvicked people in their tents of vvarre.

div.head: IVLIE.
div.p: In Iuly, the vveather vvill be ≈øo extreame hoate, vvhereby Souldiers shall not bee able to vveare their armour, and likevvi≈øe multitudes shall die for vvant of vvater, the earth shall be ≈øo parcht vvith heate that it can yeelde no foode for Cattell.

div.head: AVGVST.
div.p: In Augu≈øt, ≈øuch a grieuous plague and mortallitie vvill couer the face of the vvhole earth, that there shall not be ≈øufficient left aliue to gaither in their harue≈øt f ‚Ä¢ uites, in vvhich moneth shall come out of the Ea≈øt ≈øuch ≈øvvarmes of Foules and Flyes, that vvill deuoure the corne from the ground, and vvhere they goe, leaue the earth barren: Oh times of ≈øorrovv: oh times of vvoes, oh times of more di≈øtre≈ø≈øe then vvas that time of famine in Ieru≈øalem: you horders vp of Corne, repent, repent, your crueltie again≈øt the poore, for your extreame couetou≈øne≈ø≈øe the vvhole earth vvill be accur≈øt: yet God I hope vvill heare the pr ‚Ä¢ iers of the faithfull, and defend his nevv Ieru≈øalem from ≈øuch di≈øtre≈ø≈øe.

div.head: SEPTEMBER.
div.p: In September the earth vvill be ≈øo vnnaturall, that all manner of Cattell vvill rotte aboue the ground, vvhereof vvill breede ≈øuch ≈øtore of varmin, that the earth vvill be impoy≈øoned, and vvill receiue no fruite to encrea≈øe.

div.head: OCTOBER.
div.p: In Octrober, ≈øuch a famine and darth of Corne vvil raigne, that in ≈øome countryes the Childe vvill ≈øterue vvhile≈øt it is ≈øucking at the mothers bre≈øt, onely becau≈øe the mother can get no food to nourish her ≈øelfe nor it.

div.head: NOVEMBER.
div.p: In Nouember, a triumphant conque≈øt shall be bruted through the vvorld, of an vvorthie conquerour that takes a truce vvith all the earth, and ≈øets it in a quiet ≈øtaye.

div.head: DECEMBER.
div.p: In December all vvarres shall end e, religion preached truely through the vvorld, all things vnited vp in peace, trea≈øons and rebellions neuer thought vpon: thus all things brought to pa≈ø≈øe, vvill come that happie time the ble≈ø≈øed ≈øoules in heauen doe continually pray for.

THerefore England ca≈øt of thy cloake of ≈øinne, thy vveedes of vvickedne≈ø≈øe: no doubt but God
‚Ä¢ or his elect and cho≈øen ≈øake vvill ≈øpare this happy Iland,
vvhere his Go≈øpell is truely preached: and let this Prophe≈øie be fullfilled vpon tho≈øe misbeleeuing nations, that make a ≈øcorne of thy mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed vvorde, and Lorde vve be≈øeech thee bridle vp the Turke, that rageth again≈øt the happie ≈øtate of I≈øraell, confound the popish Antichri≈øt, vvith his confederate the King of Spaine, vvith al the re≈øidue of Englands enemies, that intends the ouerthrovv of thy nevv Ieru≈øalem, that vve may ≈øing all holy, holy, holy, to the mightie God of I≈øraell: Amen.
